questions.text: What is the correct article? Read this sentence: ___ apple is on the table.
questions.explanation: The article 'an' is used before a singular noun starting with a vowel sound, like 'apple'.

questions.text: Use the present simple tense. Read: I ___ to school every day.
questions.explanation: The present simple tense for the pronoun 'I' uses the base form of the verb, so 'go' is correct.

questions.text: Complete with the correct preposition. Read: She lives ___ Paris.
questions.explanation: The preposition 'in' is used for cities or large areas, so 'in Paris' is correct.

questions.text: Use the past simple tense. Read: Yesterday, I ___ a book.
questions.explanation: The past simple tense of 'read' is 'read' (pronounced /rɛd/), used for actions completed in the past.

questions.text: Form a question. Read: ___ is the capital of Japan?
questions.explanation: The question word 'what' is used to ask about things, like the name of a capital city.

questions.text: Use the future tense. Read: Tomorrow, I ___ visit my friend.
questions.explanation: The future tense is formed with 'will' followed by the base verb, so 'will visit' is correct.

questions.text: Correct the subject-verb agreement. Read: The dog ___ in the park.
questions.explanation: The singular subject 'dog' requires the third-person singular verb 'runs' in the present simple tense.

questions.text: Use a conditional. Read: If it rains, I ___ stay home.
questions.explanation: In a first conditional sentence, the present simple ('rains') is followed by 'will' plus the base verb.

questions.text: Complete with an article. Read: ___ sun rises in the east.
questions.explanation: The definite article 'the' is used for unique nouns like 'sun'.

questions.text: Use present continuous. Read: Right now, she ___ a song.
questions.explanation: The present continuous tense uses 'is' plus the verb with '-ing' for actions happening now.

questions.text: Choose the correct preposition. Read: I go to school ___ bus.
questions.explanation: The preposition 'by' is used to indicate the means of transport, like 'by bus'.

questions.text: Use past continuous. Read: Last night, we ___ dinner.
questions.explanation: The past continuous tense uses 'were' plus the verb with '-ing' for ongoing past actions.

questions.text: Form a negative sentence. Read: I ___ like coffee.
questions.explanation: The negative of the present simple with 'I' uses 'don’t' followed by the base verb.

questions.text: Use a modal verb. Read: You ___ finish your homework.
questions.explanation: The modal verb 'must' indicates obligation, fitting the context of completing homework.

questions.text: Complete with an article. Read: I saw ___ elephant at the zoo.
questions.explanation: The article 'an' is used before a singular noun starting with a vowel sound, like 'elephant'.

questions.text: Use present perfect. Read: I ___ just finished my work.
questions.explanation: The present perfect tense uses 'have' plus the past participle for recent actions.

questions.text: Choose the correct connector. Read: I was tired, ___ I went to bed.
questions.explanation: The connector 'so' indicates a result, linking tiredness to going to bed.

questions.text: Use a comparative. Read: This book is ___ than that one.
questions.explanation: The comparative form of 'good' is 'better', used to compare two items.

questions.text: Form a question. Read: ___ does the train leave?
questions.explanation: The question word 'when' is used to ask about time, such as a train's departure.

questions.text: Use a superlative. Read: Mount Everest is ___ mountain in the world.
questions.explanation: The superlative 'the highest' is used to describe the top degree of a quality among many items.

questions.text: Complete with a preposition. Read: The cat is ___ the table.
questions.explanation: The preposition 'on' is used for surfaces, like a table.

questions.text: Use past perfect. Read: She ___ left before I arrived.
questions.explanation: The past perfect tense uses 'had' plus the past participle for actions completed before another past action.

questions.text: Use a conditional. Read: If I ___ rich, I would travel.
questions.explanation: In a second conditional, 'were' is used with 'I' for hypothetical situations.

questions.text: Correct the verb form. Read: They ___ playing football now.
questions.explanation: The present continuous for the plural subject 'they' uses 'are' plus the verb with '-ing'.

questions.text: Use an article. Read: ___ moon is bright tonight.
questions.explanation: The definite article 'the' is used for unique nouns like 'moon'.

questions.text: Form a negative. Read: She ___ going to the party.
questions.explanation: The negative of the present continuous for 'she' uses 'isn't' (is not) plus the verb with '-ing'.

questions.text: Use a modal. Read: I ___ swim when I was five.
questions.explanation: The modal 'could' indicates past ability, suitable for describing swimming at age five.

questions.text: Complete with a preposition. Read: We meet ___ Sunday mornings.
questions.explanation: The preposition 'on' is used for specific days, like 'Sunday mornings'.

questions.text: Use future continuous. Read: Tomorrow, I ___ studying.
questions.explanation: The future continuous tense uses 'will be' plus the verb with '-ing' for ongoing future actions.

questions.text: Use a connector. Read: I studied hard, ___ I passed the test.
questions.explanation: The connector 'so' indicates a result, linking studying to passing the test.

questions.text: Form a question. Read: ___ is your favorite color?
questions.explanation: The question word 'what' is used to ask about preferences, like a favorite color.

questions.text: Use a comparative. Read: This car is ___ than that one.
questions.explanation: The comparative form of 'fast' is 'faster', used to compare two items.

questions.text: Correct the verb. Read: The children ___ in the garden.
questions.explanation: The present continuous for the plural subject 'children' uses 'are' plus the verb with '-ing'.

questions.text: Use an article. Read: I need ___ umbrella today.
questions.explanation: The article 'an' is used before a singular noun starting with a vowel sound, like 'umbrella'.

questions.text: Use present perfect continuous. Read: I ___ working all day.
questions.explanation: The present perfect continuous uses 'have been' plus the verb with '-ing' for ongoing actions.

questions.text: Use a preposition. Read: The book is ___ the shelf.
questions.explanation: The preposition 'on' is used for surfaces, like a shelf.

questions.text: Form a negative. Read: He ___ like to travel.
questions.explanation: The negative of the present simple for 'he' uses 'doesn’t' followed by the base verb.

questions.text: Use a modal. Read: You ___ be careful on the road.
questions.explanation: The modal 'should' indicates advice, suitable for being careful on the road.

questions.text: Use a superlative. Read: This is ___ day of my life.
questions.explanation: The superlative 'the best' is used to describe the top degree of a quality among many.

questions.text: Form a question. Read: ___ are you going tomorrow?
questions.explanation: The question word 'where' is used to ask about a location or destination.
